abstract.p: Patricia Dilks, after tying for third place in election, loses opportunity to serve on Pine Hill (NJ) School Board when she loses coin toss to incumbent Mary Jane Oerhl (S)

block.p: Patricia Dilks lost her opportunity to serve on the Pine Hill School Board by the slimmest of margins -- the width of a new Sacajawea gold dollar. On Tuesday, Ms. Dilks lost a coin toss to Mary Jane Oerhl, an incumbent, for the final seat on the nine-member board in the small Camden County town. Last month, Ms. Dilks and Ms. Oerhl tied with 177 votes for third place; three three-year seats were up in the election. According to the Pine Hill schools superintendent, Don Falato, neither woman wanted a recount, since it might cost them personally several hundred dollars, nor did they want a runoff election, which might have cost taxpayers as much as $3,000. So they settled on the coin flip. Ms. Dilks chose heads. County Superintendent Daniel Mastrobuono flipped. The coin landed on tails, and Ms. Oerhl was back on the board.
